text: Python is all about writing beautiful code.
So, I was running pylint to check the "beautifulness" of my code, when I bump into something:
From this part of my code:

code:
for myvar1, myvar2 in mylist:
    # Do stuff just using myvar2

text: mylist is a list of tuples, so I'm unwrapping the tuples into two variables (myvar1 and myvar2).
I'm defining those two variables just to unwrap the second one, because I don't need the other.
So, here's my question: Is there a way to tell the interpreter to unwrap the tuple, but not assing the first part (for example).
In some other languages you can do something like:

code:
for _, myvar in mylist:
    # Do stuff with myvar

for *, myvar in mylist:
    # Do stuff with myvar

text: That means: I don't care about the first part of the tuple, I just need the second one.

childList.text: I don't care about the first part of the tuple, I just need the second one.

text: NOTE: I know that this could be an option for what I'm asking:

code:
for mytuple in mylist:
    # Do stuff with mytuple[1]

text: But that's by far less readable.
